publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

monogr.title: The posies of George Gascoigne Esquire
monogr.author: Gascoigne, George

div.head: The Prologue or argument.
div.p: I Suppose you are assembled here, supposing to reape the fruite of my trauayles: and to be playne, I meane presently to presente you vvith a Comedie called Supposes: the verye name vvherof may peraduenture driue into euery of your heades a sundry Suppose, to suppose, the meaning of our supposes. Some percase vvill suppose vve meane to occupie your eares vvith sophisticall handling of subtill Suppositions. Some other vvil suppose vve go about to discipher vnto you some queint conceiptes, vvhich hitherto haue bene onely supposed as it vvere in shadovves: and some I see smyling as though they supposed vve vvould trouble you vvith the vaine suppose of some vvanton Suppose. But vnderstand, this our Suppose is nothing else but a mystaking or imagination of one thing for an other. For you shall see the master supposed for the seruant, the seruant for the master: the freeman for a slaue, and the bondslaue for a freeman: the stranger for a vvell knovven friend, and the familiar for a stranger. But vvhat? I suppose that euen already you suppose me very fonde, that haue so simply disclosed vnto you the subtilties of these our Supposes: vvhere othervvise in deede I suppose you shoulde haue hearde almoste the laste of our Supposes, before you coulde haue supposed anye of them arighte. Let this then suffise.
